title: J05-4003

sentences.text: We present a novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable , non-parallel corpora .
We train a maximum entropy classifier that , given a pair of sentences , can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other .
Using this approach , we extract parallel data from large Chinese , Arabic , and English non-parallel newspaper corpora .
We evaluate the quality of the extracted data by showing that it improves the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system .
We also show that a good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with a very small parallel corpus -LRB- 100,000 words -RRB- and exploiting a large non-parallel corpus .
Thus , our method can be applied with great benefit to language pairs for which only scarce resources are available .

Entity-a_novel_method_for_discovering_pa.label: a novel method for discovering parallel sentences
aliases: a novel method for discovering parallel sentences
Entity-a_novel_method_for_discovering_pa.description: A novel method for discovering parallel sentences refers to a technique that utilizes a maximum entropy classifier to identify translation pairs from comparable, non-parallel corpora, thereby enabling the extraction of parallel data to enhance machine translation systems.

mentions.local_name: a novel method for discovering parallel sentences

Entity-method.label: method
Entity-method.description: The method refers to a novel approach for discovering parallel sentences in comparable, non-parallel corpora using a maximum entropy classifier to determine sentence translations.

Entity-this_approach.label: this approach
Entity-this_approach.description: This approach refers to a novel methodology for extracting parallel sentences from non-parallel corpora using a maximum entropy classifier to identify translations between sentence pairs.

Entity-large_chinese__arabic__and_englis.label: large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora
aliases: large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora
Entity-large_chinese__arabic__and_englis.description: The term 'large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora' refers to extensive collections of newspaper articles in Chinese, Arabic, and English that are not aligned or translated, used as a resource for extracting parallel sentences to improve machine translation systems.

mentions.local_name: large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora

Entity-a_novel_method.label: a novel method
Entity-a_novel_method.description: A novel method refers to a technique for discovering parallel sentences in comparable, non-parallel corpora using a maximum entropy classifier to determine if sentence pairs are translations of each other.

Entity-comparable__non-parallel_corpus.label: comparable, non-parallel corpora
Entity-comparable__non-parallel_corpus.description: Comparable, non-parallel corpora refer to collections of texts in different languages that are not direct translations of each other but share thematic or topical similarities, allowing for the extraction of parallel sentences through computational methods.

Entity-translation.label: translations
Entity-translation.description: Translations refer to pairs of sentences that convey the same meaning in different languages, which can be identified using a maximum entropy classifier in the context of extracting parallel data from non-parallel corpora.

Entity-parallel_sentence.label: parallel sentences
Entity-parallel_sentence.description: Parallel sentences refer to pairs of sentences that are translations of each other, identified within comparable, non-parallel corpora for the purpose of improving machine translation systems.

Entity-non-parallel_corpus.label: non-parallel corpora
Entity-non-parallel_corpus.description: Non-parallel corpora are collections of texts in different languages that do not have a direct one-to-one correspondence in terms of content or structure, often used for comparative linguistic studies and machine translation.

Entity-parallel_corpus.label: parallel corpus
Entity-parallel_corpus.description: A parallel corpus is a collection of texts that are aligned in two or more languages, used for linguistic research and machine translation.

Entity-very_small_parallel_corpus.label: very small parallel corpus
Entity-very_small_parallel_corpus.description: A very small parallel corpus is a limited dataset consisting of aligned text in two or more languages, typically used for training or evaluating machine translation systems.

Entity-translation_of_each_other.label: translations of each other
Entity-translation_of_each_other.description: The term 'translations of each other' refers to pairs of sentences that convey the same meaning in different languages, allowing for the identification of parallel data in non-parallel corpora through a classification method.

Entity-the_quality_of_the_extracted_data.label: the quality of the extracted data
aliases: the quality of the extracted data
Entity-the_quality_of_the_extracted_data.description: The quality of the extracted data refers to the effectiveness and reliability of the parallel sentences obtained from non-parallel corpora, as measured by their ability to enhance the performance of a statistical machine translation system.

mentions.local_name: the quality of the extracted data

Entity-large_non-parallel_corpus.label: large non-parallel corpus
Entity-large_non-parallel_corpus.description: A large non-parallel corpus is a substantial collection of text data that consists of documents in one language without corresponding translations in another language, used for various linguistic and computational tasks.

Entity-a_pair_of_sentence.label: a pair of sentences
Entity-a_pair_of_sentence.description: A pair of sentences refers to two sentences that are analyzed together to determine if they are translations of each other in the context of discovering parallel sentences from non-parallel corpora.

Entity-parallel_data.label: parallel data
Entity-parallel_data.description: Parallel data refers to a type of linguistic resource that consists of pairs of texts in different languages that are translations of each other, used for tasks such as machine translation and linguistic analysis.

Entity-good-quality_mt_system.label: good-quality MT system
Entity-good-quality_mt_system.description: A good-quality MT system is a machine translation system that produces accurate and fluent translations from one language to another, typically leveraging both parallel and non-parallel corpora for training.

Entity-maximum_entropy_classifier.label: maximum entropy classifier
Entity-maximum_entropy_classifier.description: A maximum entropy classifier is a statistical model used in machine learning that predicts outcomes based on the principle of maximizing entropy, ensuring that the model is as unbiased as possible given the constraints of the training data.

Entity-100000_word.label: 100,000 words
Entity-100000_word.description: 100,000 words refers to the minimum size of a small parallel corpus required to build a good-quality machine translation system from scratch.

Entity-performance.label: performance
Entity-performance.description: In this context, 'performance' refers to the effectiveness or quality of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system, as measured by its ability to produce accurate translations after utilizing the extracted parallel data.

Entity-state-of-the-art_statistical_mach.label: state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system
aliases: the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system
Entity-state-of-the-art_statistical_mach.description: A state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system is an advanced computational system that utilizes statistical methods to automatically translate text from one language to another with high accuracy and efficiency.

mentions.local_name: the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system

Entity-statistical_machine_translation_s.label: statistical machine translation system
Entity-statistical_machine_translation_s.description: A statistical machine translation system is a computational framework that uses statistical models to automatically translate text from one language to another by analyzing large amounts of bilingual text data.

Entity-newspaper_corpus.label: newspaper corpora
Entity-newspaper_corpus.description: Newspaper corpora refer to collections of texts derived from newspapers, which are used for linguistic research, data analysis, and various computational applications.

Entity-mt_system.label: MT system
Entity-mt_system.description: An MT system is a technology designed to automatically translate text from one language to another using computational methods.

Entity-language_pair.label: language pairs
Entity-language_pair.description: Language pairs refer to combinations of two different languages that are used together for translation, communication, or linguistic analysis.

Entity-sentence.label: sentences
Entity-sentence.description: Sentences are linguistic units that consist of a group of words expressing a complete thought, typically containing a subject and a predicate.

Entity-extracted_data.label: extracted data
Entity-extracted_data.description: Extracted data refers to information that has been obtained and processed from a source for analysis or use in various applications.

Entity-chinese.label: Chinese
Entity-chinese.description: Chinese refers to the language spoken by the people of China, which is also a nationality and a national language.

Entity-arabic.label: Arabic
Entity-arabic.description: Arabic refers to a Semitic language that is widely spoken in the Arab world and serves as the national language of several countries.

Entity-english.label: English
Entity-english.description: English refers to a West Germanic language that is the primary language spoken in England and is widely used as a global lingua franca.

Entity-scarce_resource.label: scarce resources
Entity-scarce_resource.description: Scarce resources refer to materials, assets, or inputs that are limited in quantity and not readily available for use or consumption.

summary: We present a novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable , non-parallel corpora . We train a maximum entropy classifier that , given a pair of sentences , can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other . Using this approach , we extract parallel data from large Chinese , Arabic , and English non-parallel newspaper corpora . We evaluate the quality of the extracted data by showing that it improves the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system . We also show that a good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with a very small parallel corpus -LRB- 100,000 words -RRB- and exploiting a large non-parallel corpus . Thus , our method can be applied with great benefit to language pairs for which only scarce resources are available .

Predicate-is_for_discovering.label: is for discovering
Predicate-is_for_discovering.description: The predicate 'is for discovering' indicates that the subject serves a purpose or function related to the act of uncovering, identifying, or gaining knowledge about the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject is a means or tool that facilitates the exploration or revelation of the characteristics, properties, or existence of the object.

Predicate-discovers.label: discovers
Predicate-discovers.description: The predicate 'discovers' indicates an action where the subject identifies, uncovers, or reveals the existence or nature of the object. It implies a process of exploration or investigation that leads to new knowledge or understanding about the object in question.

Predicate-can_determine.label: can determine
Predicate-can_determine.description: The predicate 'can determine' indicates the ability of the subject to ascertain, identify, or establish the nature, characteristics, or relationship of the object. It implies a capacity for analysis or evaluation that leads to a conclusion or understanding regarding the object in question.

Predicate-given.label: given
Predicate-given.description: The predicate 'given' establishes a relationship where the subject is provided with or assumes the existence of the object, which serves as a condition, context, or input for the subject's operation or function.

Predicate-determines.label: determines
Predicate-determines.description: The predicate 'determines' indicates a relationship where the subject has a defining influence or authority over the object, establishing a condition or outcome that is essential or necessary for the existence, nature, or characteristics of the object. In this context, the subject plays a crucial role in shaping, guiding, or controlling the properties or behaviors of the object.

Predicate-extracts.label: extracts
Predicate-extracts.description: The predicate 'extracts' indicates an action where the subject is actively obtaining or deriving specific information, elements, or resources from the object. This process involves identifying and isolating relevant components from a broader context, thereby transforming the object into a more usable or accessible form for the subject's purposes.

Predicate-improves.label: improves
Predicate-improves.description: The predicate 'improves' indicates a positive change or enhancement in the subject, suggesting that it becomes better or more effective in some way as a result of its relationship with the object. In this context, the subject experiences an increase in quality, performance, or capability due to the influence or characteristics of the object.

Predicate-can_be_built_from.label: can be built from
Predicate-can_be_built_from.description: The predicate 'can be built from' indicates a relationship where the subject is constructed or developed using the resources, components, or foundational elements represented by the object. It implies that the object provides the necessary basis or materials that enable the creation or formation of the subject.

Predicate-can_be_built_by_exploiting.label: can be built by exploiting
Predicate-can_be_built_by_exploiting.description: The predicate 'can be built by exploiting' indicates a relationship where the subject is capable of being constructed or developed through the utilization of the resources or elements represented by the object. It implies that the object provides essential components, data, or methodologies that facilitate the creation or enhancement of the subject.

Predicate-can_be_applied_to.label: can be applied to
Predicate-can_be_applied_to.description: The predicate 'can be applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject is capable of being utilized or implemented in relation to the object. It suggests that the subject possesses qualities, features, or functionalities that make it suitable for use with the object, thereby establishing a functional or operational connection between the two.

Predicate-can_be_applied_with_great_bene.label: can be applied with great benefit to
Predicate-can_be_applied_with_great_bene.description: The predicate 'can be applied with great benefit to' indicates that the subject possesses qualities or characteristics that make it particularly useful or advantageous when utilized in relation to the object. This suggests a positive impact or enhancement that results from the application of the subject in the context of the object, highlighting the effectiveness and value of the subject in achieving beneficial outcomes.

Predicate-for_which.label: for which
Predicate-for_which.description: The predicate 'for which' establishes a relationship of purpose or relevance between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is associated with or serves as a context for the object. It implies that the object is a consideration or factor that pertains to the subject, often highlighting a specific condition or situation that affects the subject.

Predicate-is_a.label: is a
Predicate-is_a.description: The predicate 'is a' establishes a classification or categorization relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject belongs to the category defined by the object. It asserts that the subject exemplifies or fulfills the characteristics of the object, thereby providing a way to understand the nature or type of the subject in relation to a broader category.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or equivalence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject can be defined or characterized by the object, suggesting that they are fundamentally the same in some respect or that the object provides a specific classification or description of the subject.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates a hierarchical relationship where the subject is a specific instance or category that falls under a more general category represented by the object. This relationship signifies that the object encompasses a wider scope or a more inclusive classification than the subject, allowing for the organization of concepts in a taxonomy or classification system.
